advert.description: <br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH AD #2 (1984)</strong></font><br><blockquote>"Electron, software in profusion"</blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> U.S. ADVERT #2 (1979)</strong></font><br><blockquote>This is one of the first adverts showing a one computer dedicated software range. In 1979, the computer manufacturers understood that it was not enough any more to sell hardware and that the success of a computer depended now on the range and quality of the software that came with it.<br><br> Advert said:<br><br> <font color="#666666">The simple fact is nobody - nobody in the personal computer industry - offers more software than Ohio Scientific! Right now, as you read this, Ohio Scientific has just about 2 million bytes of software available for our C4P MF computer.</font> <br><br> <b>Kurt Vogel</b> adds:<br><font color="#666666"> I'd like to mention that Aardvark Software in Michigan was one of the better vendors of software for the C4P games.</font> </blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH ADVERT (FEBRUARY 1982)</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> OEMS WANTED</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> NEW ZEALAND REVIEW</strong></font><br><blockquote>Review from a New Zealand magazine. Notice the prices in Australian$ at the bottom right of the page.<p class="petitgris">Thanks to <b>Murray Moffatt</b> from New Zealand</p></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> US ADVERT </strong></font><br><blockquote>advert said<br><br><font color="#666666"> ...If you want a computer that won't be obsolete in a few years, buy an MSX.<br> If you want one of the best-selling MSX computers in Japan, buy a Toshiba HX10.</font></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> PROMO PIC #5</strong></font><br><blockquote>This picture was used to promote the educative potential of the TO-7/70. This poor student is studying economic politics... <br><br> As usual, no cables are shown... the tape recorder is thus useless... Will someone tell him ?</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> STUPID PICTURE</strong></font><br><blockquote>An 80's beautiful (!) woman tries to convince us that it's very exciting to work with an Alpha Plus...</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> ACE 1000 ADVERT (1982)</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> ADVERT #3</strong></font><br><blockquote>This man seems not to be so happy being more productive...<br> Note he uses a paper tape puncher to save newspaper articles. </blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> PROMOTIONAL PICT.</strong></font><br><blockquote>The HP-150 was widely used in industry by engineers and scientists.</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH ADVERT (1982)</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> JAPANESE AD</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FIRST U.S. AD (1982)</strong></font><br><blockquote>A discreet advert and a nice monitor.</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> U.S. AD (1983)</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH AD</strong></font><br><blockquote>Advert said : <br><br> ''The computer which carried away America"<br><br> ''With its portable computers, Compaq became world number two on the market of the 16 bits computers. With a turnover of 240 million dollars in one year and a half, this young company established in Houston obtained the growth rate record of the American economic history." </blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> PROMO PIC #2</strong></font><br><blockquote>TO-7/70 playing AIRBUS, a flight sim...</blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> PROMO PIC #4</strong></font><br><blockquote>This guy is so good as running his budget that he has become rich and bought himself a TO-7/70 ! Or did he get rich since he bought its TO-7/70 ? Anyway he is now smoking cigars and reads stock market newspapers... great</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> ITALIAN AD #3</strong></font><br><blockquote><p class="petitgris">Courtesy of <b>http://angelmemories.cjb.net/</b></p></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> JAPANESE ADVERT</strong></font><br><blockquote>Quite impressive, non ?!<p class="petitgris">Thanks to <a href="http://www.page.sannet.ne.jp/sasajima/pc/cata/"><img src="http://www.page.sannet.ne.jp/sasajima/pc/cata/ban_pc1s.gif" border="0"></a> for the picture</p></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> ACE 1000 ADVERT(1982) #2</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> DOCS</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> ADVERT (MAY 1984)</strong></font><br><blockquote>French advert</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH ADVERT (DEC.1981)</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>

computer.description:
This is a brasilian Tandy TRS-80 Model III compatible system.
It didn't sell well as the CP-500 was a too popular TRS-80 compatible system in Brazil.
In 1985, a new model named Naja 800 was marketed. It had a 14 Kb EPROM, 128 Kb RAM, built-in monitor, 70 keys keyboard with numeric keypad and a hard-disk.
Sources : Computadores Brasileiros Clube Old Bits
computer.keyboard: QWERTY keyboard with numeric keyboard, 65 keys, auto-repeat, portuguese special characters
computer.media: Up to four optional 5''1/4 disk-drives (163 kb)
computer.name: Naja
computer.ports: Parallel port, 6 expansion slots, tape interface (500 and 1500 bauds), video output
